19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No - we always had bread, milk, potatoes, in sufficient quantity.
Eggs, meat, lard were sometimes short.
Porridge was often a main supper dish.
Soup - of many kinds also a main dish.
Wild game though none too plentiful helped greatly.
Bush rabbits were a real standby the first two years, we children set snares + tended them daily - no rabbit - no dinner.
We soon learned that + became experts with snare wire.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Homemade Bread - was the first most important to keep a good supply, as there was no quick yeast method. Baking Powder Biscuits + Bannock were the substitutes also Pancakes + Hop Jocks. Jam + Grub were the usual spreads. Potatoes were used at every meal - not so much canning of veg. + meats. More salted meats were used in summer especially. Children's appetites were not so finicky as now. If you don't eat, someone else will, that's it. All lived on more in the open air - appetites were keener of the need for plain substantial food was there.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Since 1912, I have reared a family of nine children, on our original ¼ sec. my husband's homestead. We could never afford to buy prepared foods + relied mostly on our own grown fruits, meats, vegetables, dairy products. Only this past three years - since we are only three - have we bought packaged foods or soups etc. + a little fresh meat in summer.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Eastern Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

In 1905 there was a local store where most needed groceries were purchased, within two miles of us. Then the railroad came thru later that year, + we had several stores near. Butter + eggs were given in trade for the weeks groceries - when they could be spared. Crockery was much used for butter packing + the pork was brined in barrels. In winter Beef was hung by the quarter + frozen, also cut up + frozen. Fish was purchased at 4c a lb frozen - from settlers or Indians that went north to fish. Quality of foods was very good - but not so refined + handled in larger bulk than at present. Matches were made of sulphur - that really fizzed + choked you when lit.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the early days as compared to today.

Homemade bread was the first meal cooked for breakfast. As the weather got colder, we also had pancakes and hotcakes. Potatoes were used extensively in the winter months. Children often helped with the cooking, especially when there were no adults around.

If you don't eat some other way, then it's hard to believe how much our lives have changed over the years.

Since 1973, I have raised a family of nine children on our own land. We could never afford to buy prepared foods, so we relied on our own grown fruits, vegetables, and meat products. Only three times did we buy packaged foods or soups, etc., for a little extra meat in summer.

21. What changes occurred in the consumption of food during your lifetime?

In the early days, people ate mostly what they grew themselves. Today, we rely on processed foods and convenience items. The variety of foods available has increased dramatically.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and earlier foods in other ways, including plans for the future.

In the early days, people bought their groceries at local stores. Today, we rely on supermarkets and convenience stores for our food needs.

In 1905, there was a local store where most needed groceries were purchased within five miles of us. Then the railroad came through, and we began to buy our groceries from larger stores. The quality of food improved significantly, and we could buy fresh produce year-round.

Beef was always a favorite, and we would often buy it by the quarter. Fish was purchased at the market, and we would freeze it for later use.

The quality of food was very good, but not as refined as it is today. Matches were made of sulphur, which really burned and smelled.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Homemade Bread - was the first most important to keep a good supply, as there was no quick-pan method. Baking Powder Biscuits + Bannock were the substitutes also Pancakes + Flat Jacks. Jams + Syrups were the usual spreads. Potatoes were used at every meal - not so much canning of veg. & meats.

More salted meats were used in summer especially. Children's appetites were not so finicky as now. If you don't eat someone else will, that's it.

All lived more in the open air - after times were keener of the need for plain substantial food was there.
